translation.text: One Universal Creator God. By The Grace Of The True Guru:

text: ਸਿਧ ਸਭਾ ਕਰਿ ਆਸਣਿ ਬੈਠੇ ਸੰਤ ਸਭਾ ਜੈਕਾਰੋ ॥
section: Ramkali - Sidh Gosht (Conversations With The Perfected Masters)

translation.text: The Siddhas formed an assembly; sitting in their Yogic postures, they shouted, "Salute this gathering of Saints."

transliteration.text: sidh sabhā kar āsan baithē sant sabhā jaikārō .

melody.description: The emotions in Ramkali are like those of a wise teacher disciplining their student. The student is aware of the pain of learning, but is still conscious of the fact that ultimately it is for the best. In this way Ramkali conveys the change from all that we are familiar with, to something we are certain will be better.

author.author: Guru Nanak Dev
author.description:
Guru Nanak Dev Ji [1469 - 1539] was the first Guru of the Sikhs born in a village named Talwandi which is now called Nankana Sahib and is in Pakistan. As a child Guru Nanak spent most of his time in isolation and meditation. He slept only for a few hours, ate small quantities of food and spoke little.

One day he disappeared while having his morning bath and reappeared 3 days later and said: There is no Hindu and there is no Muslim. By saying this he meant that titles were meaningless because all of humanity is one and the light of God shines within everyone.

text: ਤਿਸੁ ਆਗੈ ਰਹਰਾਸਿ ਹਮਾਰੀ ਸਾਚਾ ਅਪਰ ਅਪਾਰੋ ॥
section: Ramkali - Sidh Gosht (Conversations With The Perfected Masters)

translation.text: I offer my salutation to the One who is true, infinite and incomparably beautiful.

transliteration.text: tis āgai raharās hamārī sāchā apar apārō .

translation.text: I cut off my head, and offer it to Him; I dedicate my body and mind to Him.

translation.text: "The world-ocean is treacherous and impassable; how can one cross over?

translation.text: with one's consciousness focused on the Word of the Shabad, one crosses over the terrifying world-ocean. O Nanak, chant the Naam, the Name of the Lord.

author.description:
Guru Nanak Dev Ji [1469 - 1539] was the first Guru of the Sikhs born in a village named Talwandi which is now called Nankana Sahib and is in Pakistan. As a child Guru Nanak spent most of his time in isolation and meditation. He slept only for a few hours, ate small quantities of food and spoke little.

section: Ramkali - Sidh Gosht (Conversations With The Perfected Masters)

translation.text: "Where did we come from? Where are we going? Where will we be absorbed?

transliteration.text: kahā tē āvai kahā ih jāvai kahā ih rahai samāī .

melody.description: The emotions in Ramkali are like those of a wise teacher disciplining their student. The student is aware of the pain of learning, but is still conscious of the fact that ultimately it is for the best. In this way Ramkali conveys the change from all that we are familiar with, to something we are certain will be better.

author.author: Guru Nanak Dev
author.description:
Guru Nanak Dev Ji [1469 - 1539] was the first Guru of the Sikhs born in a village named Talwandi which is now called Nankana Sahib and is in Pakistan. As a child Guru Nanak spent most of his time in isolation and meditation. He slept only for a few hours, ate small quantities of food and spoke little.

One day he disappeared while having his morning bath and reappeared 3 days later and said: There is no Hindu and there is no Muslim. By saying this he meant that titles were meaningless because all of humanity is one and the light of God shines within everyone.

text: ਏਸੁ ਸਬਦ ਕਉ ਜੋ ਅਰਥਾਵੈ ਤਿਸੁ ਗੁਰ ਤਿਲੁ ਨ ਤਮਾਈ ॥
section: Ramkali - Sidh Gosht (Conversations With The Perfected Masters)

translation.text: One who reveals the meaning of this Shabad is the Guru, who has no greed at all.

transliteration.text: ēs sabad kau jō arathāvai tis gur til n tamāī .

melody.description: The emotions in Ramkali are like those of a wise teacher disciplining their student. The student is aware of the pain of learning, but is still conscious of the fact that ultimately it is for the best. text: ਕਿਉ ਤਤੈ ਅਵਿਗਤੈ ਪਾਵੈ ਗੁਰਮੁਖਿ ਲਗੈ ਪਿਆਰੋ ॥
section: Ramkali - Sidh Gosht (Conversations With The Perfected Masters)

translation.text: How can one find the essence of the unmanifest reality? How does one become Gurmukh, and enshrine love for the Lord?

transliteration.text: kiu tatai avigatai pāvai guramukh lagai piārō .

melody.description: The emotions in Ramkali are like those of a wise teacher disciplining their student. section: Ramkali - Sidh Gosht (Conversations With The Perfected Masters)

translation.text: He Himself is consciousness, He Himself is the Creator; share with us, Nanak, your wisdom."

transliteration.text: āpē suratā āpē karatā kah nānak bīchārō .

section: Ramkali - Sidh Gosht (Conversations With The Perfected Masters)

translation.text: By His Command we come, and by His Command we go; by His Command, we merge in absorption.

transliteration.text: hukamē āvai hukamē jāvai hukamē rahai samāī .

section: Ramkali - Sidh Gosht (Conversations With The Perfected Masters)

translation.text: Through the Perfect Guru, live the Truth; through the Word of the Shabad, the state of dignity is attained. ||22||

transliteration.text: pūrē gur tē sāch kamāvai gat mit sabadē pāī .22.

text: ਆਦਿ ਕਉ ਬਿਸਮਾਦੁ ਬੀਚਾਰੁ ਕਥੀਅਲੇ ਸੁੰਨ ਨਿਰੰਤਰਿ ਵਾਸੁ ਲੀਆ ॥
section: Ramkali - Sidh Gosht (Conversations With The Perfected Masters)

translation.text: We can only express a sense of wonder about the beginning. The absolute abided endlessly deep within Himself then.

transliteration.text: ād kau bisamād bīchār kathīalē sunn nirantar vās līā .

text: ਅਕਲਪਤ ਮੁਦ੍ਰਾ ਗੁਰ ਗਿਆਨੁ ਬੀਚਾਰੀਅਲੇ ਘਟਿ ਘਟਿ ਸਾਚਾ ਸਰਬ ਜੀਆ ॥
section: Ramkali - Sidh Gosht (Conversations With The Perfected Masters)

translation.text: Consider freedom from desire to be the ear-rings of the Guru's spiritual wisdom. The True Lord, the Soul of all, dwells within each and every heart.

transliteration.text: akalapat mudrā gur giān bīchārīalē ghat ghat sāchā sarab jīā .

In this way Ramkali conveys the change from all that we are familiar with, to something we are certain will be better.

text: ਗੁਰ ਬਚਨੀ ਅਵਿਗਤਿ ਸਮਾਈਐ ਤਤੁ ਨਿਰੰਜਨੁ ਸਹਜਿ ਲਹੈ ॥
section: Ramkali - Sidh Gosht (Conversations With The Perfected Masters)

translation.text: Through the Guru's Word, one merges in the absolute, and intuitively receives the immaculate essence.

transliteration.text: gur bachanī avigat samāīai tat niranjan sahaj lahai .

section: Ramkali - Sidh Gosht (Conversations With The Perfected Masters)

translation.text: O Nanak, that Sikh who seeks and finds the Way does not serve any other.

transliteration.text: nānak dūjī kār n karanī sēvai sikh s khōj lahai .

section: Ramkali - Sidh Gosht (Conversations With The Perfected Masters)

translation.text: Wonderful and amazing is His Command; He alone realizes His Command and knows the true way of life of His creatures.

transliteration.text: hukam bisamād hukam pashānai jī jugat sach jānai sōī .

section: Ramkali - Sidh Gosht (Conversations With The Perfected Masters)

translation.text: One who eradicates his self-conceit becomes free of desire; he alone is a Yogi, who enshrines the True Lord deep within. ||23||

transliteration.text: āp mēt nirālam hōvai antar sāch jōgī kahīai sōī .23.

section: Ramkali - Sidh Gosht (Conversations With The Perfected Masters)

translation.text: From His state of absolute existence, He assumed the immaculate form; from formless, He assumed the supreme form.

transliteration.text: avigatō niramāil upajē niragun tē saragun thīā .

section: Ramkali - Sidh Gosht (Conversations With The Perfected Masters)

translation.text: By pleasing the True Guru, the supreme status is obtained, and one is absorbed in the True Word of the Shabad.

transliteration.text: satigur parachai param pad pāīai sāchai sabad samāi līā .

section: Ramkali - Sidh Gosht (Conversations With The Perfected Masters)

translation.text: He knows the True Lord as the One and only; he sends his egotism and duality far away.

transliteration.text: ēkē kau sach ēkā jānai haumai dūjā dūr kīā .

translation.text: He alone is a Yogi, who realizes the Word of the Guru's Shabad; the lotus of the heart blossoms forth within.

transliteration.text: sō jōgī gur sabad pashānai antar kamal pragās thīā .

section: Ramkali - Sidh Gosht (Conversations With The Perfected Masters)

translation.text: If one remains dead while yet alive, then he understands everything; he knows the Lord deep within himself, who is kind and compassionate to all.

transliteration.text: jīvat marai tā sabh kish sūjhai antar jānai sarab daiā .

section: Ramkali - Sidh Gosht (Conversations With The Perfected Masters)

translation.text: O Nanak, he is blessed with glorious greatness; he realizes himself in all beings. ||24||

transliteration.text: nānak tā kau milai vadāī āp pashānai sarab jīā .24.

section: Ramkali - Sidh Gosht (Conversations With The Perfected Masters)

translation.text: We emerge from Truth, and merge into Truth again. The pure being merges into the One True Lord.

transliteration.text: sāchau upajai sāch samāvai sāchē sūchē ēk maiā .

section: Ramkali - Sidh Gosht (Conversations With The Perfected Masters)

translation.text: The false come, and find no place of rest; in duality, they come and go.

transliteration.text: jhūthē āvah thavar n pāvah dūjai āvā gaun bhaiā .

text: ਆਵਾ ਗਉਣੁ ਮਿਟੈ ਗੁਰ ਸਬਦੀ ਆਪੇ ਪਰਖੈ ਬਖਸਿ ਲਇਆ ॥
section: Ramkali - Sidh Gosht (Conversations With The Perfected Masters)

translation.text: This coming and going in reincarnation is ended through the Word of the Guru's Shabad; the Lord Himself analyzes and grants His forgiveness.

transliteration.text: āvā gaun mitai gur sabadī āpē parakhai bakhas laiā .

melody.description: The emotions in Ramkali are like those of a wise teacher disciplining their student. The student is aware of the pain of learning, but is still conscious of the fact that ultimately it is for the best. In this way Ramkali conveys the change from all that we are familiar with, to something we are certain will be better.

author.author: Guru Nanak Dev
author.description:
Guru Nanak Dev Ji [1469 - 1539] was the first Guru of the Sikhs born in a village named Talwandi which is now called Nankana Sahib and is in Pakistan. As a child Guru Nanak spent most of his time in isolation and meditation. He slept only for a few hours, ate small quantities of food and spoke little.

One day he disappeared while having his morning bath and reappeared 3 days later and said: There is no Hindu and there is no Muslim. By saying this he meant that titles were meaningless because all of humanity is one and the light of God shines within everyone.

text: ਏਕਾ ਬੇਦਨ ਦੂਜੈ ਬਿਆਪੀ ਨਾਮੁ ਰਸਾਇਣੁ ਵੀਸਰਿਆ ॥
section: Ramkali - Sidh Gosht (Conversations With The Perfected Masters)

translation.text: One who suffers from the disease of duality, forgets the Naam, the source of nectar.

transliteration.text: ēkā bēdan dūjai biāpī nām rasāin vīsariā .

melody.description: The emotions in Ramkali are like those of a wise teacher disciplining their student. text: ਸੋ ਬੂਝੈ ਜਿਸੁ ਆਪਿ ਬੁਝਾਏ ਗੁਰ ਕੈ ਸਬਦਿ ਸੁ ਮੁਕਤੁ ਭਇਆ ॥
section: Ramkali - Sidh Gosht (Conversations With The Perfected Masters)

translation.text: He alone understands, whom the Lord inspires to understand. Through the Word of the Guru's Shabad, one is liberated.

transliteration.text: sō būjhai jis āp bujhāē gur kai sabad s mukat bhaiā .

section: Ramkali - Sidh Gosht (Conversations With The Perfected Masters)

translation.text: O Nanak, the Emancipator emancipates one who drives out egotism and duality. ||25||

As a child Guru Nanak spent most of his time in isolation and meditation. He slept only for a few hours, ate small quantities of food and spoke little.

One day he disappeared while having his morning bath and reappeared 3 days later and said: There is no Hindu and there is no Muslim. By saying this he meant that titles were meaningless because all of humanity is one and the light of God shines within everyone.

text: ਜਿਸ ਤੇ ਉਪਜੇ ਤਿਸ ਹੀ ਜੈਸੇ ॥
section: Ramkali - Sidh Gosht (Conversations With The Perfected Masters)

translation.text: They are like the Lord, from whom they originated.

transliteration.text: jis tē upajē tis hī jaisē .

melody.description: The emotions in Ramkali are like those of a wise teacher disciplining their student. The student is aware of the pain of learning, but is still conscious of the fact that ultimately it is for the best. In this way Ramkali conveys the change from all that we are familiar with, to something we are certain will be better.

As a child Guru Nanak spent most of his time in isolation and meditation. He slept only for a few hours, ate small quantities of food and spoke little.

One day he disappeared while having his morning bath and reappeared 3 days later and said: There is no Hindu and there is no Muslim. By saying this he meant that titles were meaningless because all of humanity is one and the light of God shines within everyone.

translation.text: Listen, O master; Nanak prays truly. Instruct your own mind.

translation.text: When He bestows His Glance of Grace, the Shabad comes to abide within the heart, and doubt is eradicated from within.

translation.text: The body and mind become immaculate, through the Immaculate Word of His Bani. Let His Name be enshrined in your mind.

translation.text: The Shabad is the Guru, to carry you across the terrifying world-ocean. Know the One Lord alone, here and hereafter.

translation.text: He has no form or color, shadow or illusion; O Nanak, realize the Shabad. ||59||

translation.text: O reclusive hermit, the True, Absolute Lord is the support of the exhaled breath, which extends out ten finger lengths.

translation.text: Eradicating the three qualities, he enshrines the Shabad within, and then, his mind is rid of egotism.

author.author: Guru Nanak Dev
author.description:
Guru Nanak Dev Ji [1469 - 1539] was the first Guru of the Sikhs born in a village named Talwandi which is now called Nankana Sahib and is in Pakistan. As a child Guru Nanak spent most of his time in isolation and meditation. He slept only for a few hours, ate small quantities of food and spoke little.

One day he disappeared while having his morning bath and reappeared 3 days later and said: There is no Hindu and there is no Muslim. By saying this he meant that titles were meaningless because all of humanity is one and the light of God shines within everyone.

text: ਸੁਖਮਨਾ ਇੜਾ ਪਿੰਗੁਲਾ ਬੂਝੈ ਜਾ ਆਪੇ ਅਲਖੁ ਲਖਾਏ ॥
section: Ramkali - Sidh Gosht (Conversations With The Perfected Masters)

translation.text: He understands the Sushmana, Ida and Pingala, when the unseen Lord reveals Himself.

transliteration.text: sukhamanā irā pingulā būjhai jā āpē alakh lakhāē .

melody.description: The emotions in Ramkali are like those of a wise teacher disciplining their student. The student is aware of the pain of learning, but is still conscious of the fact that ultimately it is for the best. In this way Ramkali conveys the change from all that we are familiar with, to something we are certain will be better.

text: ਨਾਨਕ ਤਿਹੁ ਤੇ ਊਪਰਿ ਸਾਚਾ ਸਤਿਗੁਰ ਸਬਦਿ ਸਮਾਏ ॥੬੦॥
section: Ramkali - Sidh Gosht (Conversations With The Perfected Masters)

translation.text: O Nanak, the True Lord is above these three energy channels. Through the Word, the Shabad of the True Guru, one merges with Him. ||60||

transliteration.text: nānak tih tē ūpar sāchā satigur sabad samāē .60.

melody.description: The emotions in Ramkali are like those of a wise teacher disciplining their student. The student is aware of the pain of learning, but is still conscious of the fact that ultimately it is for the best. In this way Ramkali conveys the change from all that we are familiar with, to something we are certain will be better.

text: ਮਨ ਕਾ ਜੀਉ ਪਵਨੁ ਕਥੀਅਲੇ ਪਵਨੁ ਕਹਾ ਰਸੁ ਖਾਈ ॥
section: Ramkali - Sidh Gosht (Conversations With The Perfected Masters)

translation.text: "The air is said to be the soul of the mind. But what does the air feed on?

transliteration.text: man kā jīu pavan kathīalē pavan kahā ras khāī .

melody.description: The emotions in Ramkali are like those of a wise teacher disciplining their student. The student is aware of the pain of learning, but is still conscious of the fact that ultimately it is for the best. In this way Ramkali conveys the change from all that we are familiar with, to something we are certain will be better.

text: ਗਿਆਨ ਕੀ ਮੁਦ੍ਰਾ ਕਵਨ ਅਉਧੂ ਸਿਧ ਕੀ ਕਵਨ ਕਮਾਈ ॥
section: Ramkali - Sidh Gosht (Conversations With The Perfected Masters)

translation.text: What is the way of the spiritual teacher, and the reclusive hermit? What is the occupation of the Siddha?"

transliteration.text: giān kī mudrā kavan audhū sidh kī kavan kamāī .

melody.description: The emotions in Ramkali are like those of a wise teacher disciplining their student. section: Ramkali - Sidh Gosht (Conversations With The Perfected Masters)

translation.text: Without the Shabad, the essence does not come, O hermit, and the thirst of egotism does not depart.

transliteration.text: bin sabadai ras n āvai audhū haumai piās n jāī .

section: Ramkali - Sidh Gosht (Conversations With The Perfected Masters)

translation.text: Imbued with the Shabad, one finds the ambrosial essence, and remains fulfilled with the True Name.

transliteration.text: sabad ratē anmrit ras pāiā sāchē rahē aghāī .

section: Ramkali - Sidh Gosht (Conversations With The Perfected Masters)

translation.text: What is that wisdom, by which one remains steady and stable? What food brings satisfaction?

transliteration.text: kavan budh jit asathir rahīai kit bhōjan tripatāsai .

section: Ramkali - Sidh Gosht (Conversations With The Perfected Masters)

translation.text: O Nanak, when one looks upon pain and pleasure alike, through the True Guru, then he is not consumed by Death. ||61||

transliteration.text: nānak dukh sukh sam kar jāpai satigur tē kāl n grāsai .61.

translation.text: If one is not imbued with the Lord's Love, nor intoxicated with His subtle essence,

translation.text: "Where does this mind-elephant live? Where does the breath reside?

text: ਨਦਰਿ ਕਰੇ ਤਾ ਸਤਿਗੁਰੁ ਮੇਲੇ ਤਾ ਨਿਜ ਘਰਿ ਵਾਸਾ ਇਹੁ ਮਨੁ ਪਾਏ ॥
section: Ramkali - Sidh Gosht (Conversations With The Perfected Masters)

translation.text: When the Lord blesses one with His Glance of Grace, he leads him to the True Guru. Then, this mind dwells in its own home within.

transliteration.text: nadar karē tā satigur mēlē tā nij ghar vāsā ih man pāē .

melody.description: The emotions in Ramkali are like those of a wise teacher disciplining their student. The student is aware of the pain of learning, but is still conscious of the fact that ultimately it is for the best. In this way Ramkali conveys the change from all that we are familiar with, to something we are certain will be better.

author.author: Guru Nanak Dev
author.description:
Guru Nanak Dev Ji [1469 - 1539] was the first Guru of the Sikhs born in a village named Talwandi which is now called Nankana Sahib and is in Pakistan. As a child Guru Nanak spent most of his time in isolation and meditation. He slept only for a few hours, ate small quantities of food and spoke little.

One day he disappeared while having his morning bath and reappeared 3 days later and said: There is no Hindu and there is no Muslim. By saying this he meant that titles were meaningless because all of humanity is one and the light of God shines within everyone.

text: ਆਪੈ ਆਪੁ ਖਾਇ ਤਾ ਨਿਰਮਲੁ ਹੋਵੈ ਧਾਵਤੁ ਵਰਜਿ ਰਹਾਏ ॥
section: Ramkali - Sidh Gosht (Conversations With The Perfected Masters)

translation.text: When the individual consumes his egotism, he becomes immaculate, and his wandering mind is restrained.

transliteration.text: āpai āp khāi tā niramal hōvai dhāvat varaj rahāē .

melody.description: The emotions in Ramkali are like those of a wise teacher disciplining their student. The student is aware of the pain of learning, but is still conscious of the fact that ultimately it is for the best. In this way Ramkali conveys the change from all that we are familiar with, to something we are certain will be better.

text: ਕਿਉ ਮੂਲੁ ਪਛਾਣੈ ਆਤਮੁ ਜਾਣੈ ਕਿਉ ਸਸਿ ਘਰਿ ਸੂਰੁ ਸਮਾਵੈ ॥
section: Ramkali - Sidh Gosht (Conversations With The Perfected Masters)

translation.text: How can the root, the source of all be realized? How can the soul know itself? How can the sun enter into the house of the moon?

transliteration.text: kiu mūl pashānai ātam jānai kiu sas ghar sūr samāvai .

melody.description: The emotions in Ramkali are like those of a wise teacher disciplining their student. The student is aware of the pain of learning, but is still conscious of the fact that ultimately it is for the best. In this way Ramkali conveys the change from all that we are familiar with, to something we are certain will be better.

text: ਗੁਰਮੁਖਿ ਹਉਮੈ ਵਿਚਹੁ ਖੋਵੈ ਤਉ ਨਾਨਕ ਸਹਜਿ ਸਮਾਵੈ ॥੬੪॥
section: Ramkali - Sidh Gosht (Conversations With The Perfected Masters)

translation.text: The Gurmukh eliminates egotism from within; then, O Nanak, the sun naturally enters into the home of the moon. ||64||

transliteration.text: guramukh haumai vichah khōvai tau nānak sahaj samāvai .64.

The student is aware of the pain of learning, but is still conscious of the fact that ultimately it is for the best. In this way Ramkali conveys the change from all that we are familiar with, to something we are certain will be better.

text: ਇਹੁ ਮਨੁ ਨਿਹਚਲੁ ਹਿਰਦੈ ਵਸੀਅਲੇ ਗੁਰਮੁਖਿ ਮੂਲੁ ਪਛਾਣਿ ਰਹੈ ॥
section: Ramkali - Sidh Gosht (Conversations With The Perfected Masters)

translation.text: When the mind becomes steady and stable, it abides in the heart, and then the Gurmukh realizes the root, the source of all.

transliteration.text: ih man nihachal hiradai vasīalē guramukh mūl pashān rahai .

melody.description: The emotions in Ramkali are like those of a wise teacher disciplining their student. The student is aware of the pain of learning, but is still conscious of the fact that ultimately it is for the best. In this way Ramkali conveys the change from all that we are familiar with, to something we are certain will be better.

text: ਨਾਭਿ ਪਵਨੁ ਘਰਿ ਆਸਣਿ ਬੈਸੈ ਗੁਰਮੁਖਿ ਖੋਜਤ ਤਤੁ ਲਹੈ ॥
section: Ramkali - Sidh Gosht (Conversations With The Perfected Masters)

translation.text: The breath is seated in the home of the navel; the Gurmukh searches, and finds the essence of reality.

transliteration.text: nābh pavan ghar āsan baisai guramukh khōjat tat lahai .

melody.description: The emotions in Ramkali are like those of a wise teacher disciplining their student. The student is aware of the pain of learning, but is still conscious of the fact that ultimately it is for the best. In this way Ramkali conveys the change from all that we are familiar with, to something we are certain will be better.

text: ਸੁ ਸਬਦੁ ਨਿਰੰਤਰਿ ਨਿਜ ਘਰਿ ਆਛੈ ਤ੍ਰਿਭਵਣ ਜੋਤਿ ਸੁ ਸਬਦਿ ਲਹੈ ॥
section: Ramkali - Sidh Gosht (Conversations With The Perfected Masters)

translation.text: This Shabad permeates the nucleus of the self, deep within, in its own home; the Light of this Shabad pervades the three worlds.

transliteration.text: s sabad nirantar nij ghar āshai tribhavan jōt s sabad lahai .

melody.description: The emotions in Ramkali are like those of a wise teacher disciplining their student. The student is aware of the pain of learning, but is still conscious of the fact that ultimately it is for the best. In this way Ramkali conveys the change from all that we are familiar with, to something we are certain will be better.

text: ਖਾਵੈ ਦੂਖ ਭੂਖ ਸਾਚੇ ਕੀ ਸਾਚੇ ਹੀ ਤ੍ਰਿਪਤਾਸਿ ਰਹੈ ॥
section: Ramkali - Sidh Gosht (Conversations With The Perfected Masters)

translation.text: Hunger for the True Lord shall consume your pain, and through the True Lord, you shall be satisfied.

transliteration.text: khāvai dūkh bhūkh sāchē kī sāchē hī tripatās rahai .

melody.description: The emotions in Ramkali are like those of a wise teacher disciplining their student. The student is aware of the pain of learning, but is still conscious of the fact that ultimately it is for the best. In this way Ramkali conveys the change from all that we are familiar with, to something we are certain will be better.

One day he disappeared while having his morning bath and reappeared 3 days later and said: There is no Hindu and there is no Muslim. By saying this he meant that titles were meaningless because all of humanity is one and the light of God shines within everyone.

text: ਅਨਹਦ ਬਾਣੀ ਗੁਰਮੁਖਿ ਜਾਣੀ ਬਿਰਲੋ ਕੋ ਅਰਥਾਵੈ ॥
section: Ramkali - Sidh Gosht (Conversations With The Perfected Masters)

translation.text: The Gurmukh knows the unstruck sound current of the Bani; how rare are those who understand.

transliteration.text: anahad bānī guramukh jānī biralō kō arathāvai .

melody.description: The emotions in Ramkali are like those of a wise teacher disciplining their student. The student is aware of the pain of learning, but is still conscious of the fact that ultimately it is for the best. In this way Ramkali conveys the change from all that we are familiar with, to something we are certain will be better.

text: ਨਾਨਕੁ ਆਖੈ ਸਚੁ ਸੁਭਾਖੈ ਸਚਿ ਰਪੈ ਰੰਗੁ ਕਬਹੂ ਨ ਜਾਵੈ ॥੬੫॥
section: Ramkali - Sidh Gosht (Conversations With The Perfected Masters)

translation.text: Says Nanak, one who speaks the Truth is dyed in the color of Truth, which will never fade away. ||65||

transliteration.text: nānak ākhai sach subhākhai sach rapai rang kabahū n jāvai .65.

melody.description: The emotions in Ramkali are like those of a wise teacher disciplining their student. The student is aware of the pain of learning, but is still conscious of the fact that ultimately it is for the best. text: ਜਾ ਇਹੁ ਹਿਰਦਾ ਦੇਹ ਨ ਹੋਤੀ ਤਉ ਮਨੁ ਕੈਠੈ ਰਹਤਾ ॥
section: Ramkali - Sidh Gosht (Conversations With The Perfected Masters)

translation.text: "When this heart and body did not exist, where did the mind reside?

transliteration.text: jā ih hiradā dēh n hōtī tau man kaithai rahatā .

melody.description: The emotions in Ramkali are like those of a wise teacher disciplining their student. The student is aware of the pain of learning, but is still conscious of the fact that ultimately it is for the best. In this way Ramkali conveys the change from all that we are familiar with, to something we are certain will be better.

text: ਨਾਭਿ ਕਮਲ ਅਸਥੰਭੁ ਨ ਹੋਤੋ ਤਾ ਪਵਨੁ ਕਵਨ ਘਰਿ ਸਹਤਾ ॥
section: Ramkali - Sidh Gosht (Conversations With The Perfected Masters)

translation.text: When there was no support of the navel lotus, then in which home did the breath reside?

transliteration.text: nābh kamal asathanbh n hōtō tā pavan kavan ghar sahatā .

melody.description: The emotions in Ramkali are like those of a wise teacher disciplining their student. The student is aware of the pain of learning, but is still conscious of the fact that ultimately it is for the best. In this way Ramkali conveys the change from all that we are familiar with, to something we are certain will be better.

text: ਰੂਪੁ ਨ ਹੋਤੋ ਰੇਖ ਨ ਕਾਈ ਤਾ ਸਬਦਿ ਕਹਾ ਲਿਵ ਲਾਈ ॥
section: Ramkali - Sidh Gosht (Conversations With The Perfected Masters)

translation.text: When there was no form or shape, then how could anyone lovingly focus on the Shabad?

transliteration.text: rūp n hōtō rēkh n kāī tā sabad kahā liv lāī .

melody.description: The emotions in Ramkali are like those of a wise teacher disciplining their student. The student is aware of the pain of learning, but is still conscious of the fact that ultimately it is for the best. In this way Ramkali conveys the change from all that we are familiar with, to something we are certain will be better.

text: ਰਕਤੁ ਬਿੰਦੁ ਕੀ ਮੜੀ ਨ ਹੋਤੀ ਮਿਤਿ ਕੀਮਤਿ ਨਹੀ ਪਾਈ ॥
section: Ramkali - Sidh Gosht (Conversations With The Perfected Masters)

translation.text: When there was no dungeon formed from egg and sperm, who could measure the Lord's value and extent?

transliteration.text: rakat bind kī marī n hōtī mit kīmat nahī pāī .

melody.description: The emotions in Ramkali are like those of a wise teacher disciplining their student. The student is aware of the pain of learning, but is still conscious of the fact that ultimately it is for the best. In this way Ramkali conveys the change from all that we are familiar with, to something we are certain will be better.

text: ਵਰਨੁ ਭੇਖੁ ਅਸਰੂਪੁ ਨ ਜਾਪੀ ਕਿਉ ਕਰਿ ਜਾਪਸਿ ਸਾਚਾ ॥
section: Ramkali - Sidh Gosht (Conversations With The Perfected Masters)

translation.text: When color, dress and form could not be seen, how could the True Lord be known?"

transliteration.text: varan bhēkh asarūp n jāpī kiu kar jāpas sāchā .

text: ਨਾਨਕ ਨਾਮਿ ਰਤੇ ਬੈਰਾਗੀ ਇਬ ਤਬ ਸਾਚੋ ਸਾਚਾ ॥੬੬॥
section: Ramkali - Sidh Gosht (Conversations With The Perfected Masters)

translation.text: O Nanak, those who are attuned to the Naam, the Name of the Lord, are detached. Then and now, they see the Truest of the True. ||66||

transliteration.text: nānak nām ratē bairāgī ib tab sāchō sāchā .66.

text: ਹਿਰਦਾ ਦੇਹ ਨ ਹੋਤੀ ਅਉਧੂ ਤਉ ਮਨੁ ਸੁੰਨਿ ਰਹੈ ਬੈਰਾਗੀ ॥
section: Ramkali - Sidh Gosht (Conversations With The Perfected Masters)

translation.text: When the heart and the body did not exist, O hermit, then the mind resided in the absolute, detached Lord.

transliteration.text: hiradā dēh n hōtī audhū tau man sunn rahai bairāgī .

melody.description: The emotions in Ramkali are like those of a wise teacher disciplining their student. section: Ramkali - Sidh Gosht (Conversations With The Perfected Masters)

translation.text: When there was no support of the lotus of the navel, the breath remained in its own home, attuned to the Lord's Love.

transliteration.text: nābh kamal asathanbh n hōtō tā nij ghar basatau pavan anarāgī .

text: ਰੂਪੁ ਨ ਰੇਖਿਆ ਜਾਤਿ ਨ ਹੋਤੀ ਤਉ ਅਕੁਲੀਣਿ ਰਹਤਉ ਸਬਦੁ ਸੁ ਸਾਰੁ ॥
section: Ramkali - Sidh Gosht (Conversations With The Perfected Masters)

translation.text: When there was no form or shape or social class, then the Shabad, in its essence, resided in the unmanifest Lord.

transliteration.text: rūp n rēkhiā jāt n hōtī tau akulīn rahatau sabad s sār .

section: Ramkali - Sidh Gosht (Conversations With The Perfected Masters)

translation.text: When the world and the sky did not even exist, the Light of the Formless Lord filled the three worlds.

transliteration.text: gaun gagan jab tabah n hōtau tribhavan jōt āpē nirankār .

author.author: Guru Nanak Dev
author.description:
Guru Nanak Dev Ji [1469 - 1539] was the first Guru of the Sikhs born in a village named Talwandi which is now called Nankana Sahib and is in Pakistan. As a child Guru Nanak spent most of his time in isolation and meditation. He slept only for a few hours, ate small quantities of food and spoke little.

One day he disappeared while having his morning bath and reappeared 3 days later and said: There is no Hindu and there is no Muslim. By saying this he meant that titles were meaningless because all of humanity is one and the light of God shines within everyone.

text: ਵਰਨੁ ਭੇਖੁ ਅਸਰੂਪੁ ਸੁ ਏਕੋ ਏਕੋ ਸਬਦੁ ਵਿਡਾਣੀ ॥
section: Ramkali - Sidh Gosht (Conversations With The Perfected Masters)

translation.text: Color, dress and form were contained in the One Lord; the Shabad was contained in the One, Wondrous Lord.

transliteration.text: varan bhēkh asarūp s ēkō ēkō sabad vidānī .

melody.description: The emotions in Ramkali are like those of a wise teacher disciplining their student. The student is aware of the pain of learning, but is still conscious of the fact that ultimately it is for the best. In this way Ramkali conveys the change from all that we are familiar with, to something we are certain will be better.

author.author: Guru Nanak Dev
author.description:

text: ਸਾਚ ਬਿਨਾ ਸੂਚਾ ਕੋ ਨਾਹੀ ਨਾਨਕ ਅਕਥ ਕਹਾਣੀ ॥੬੭॥
section: Ramkali - Sidh Gosht (Conversations With The Perfected Masters)

translation.text: Without the True Name, no one can become pure; O Nanak, this is the Unspoken Speech. ||67||

transliteration.text: sāch binā sūchā kō nāhī nānak akath kahānī .67.

melody.description: The emotions in Ramkali are like those of a wise teacher disciplining their student. The student is aware of the pain of learning, but is still conscious of the fact that ultimately it is for the best. In this way Ramkali conveys the change from all that we are familiar with, to something we are certain will be better.

text: ਕਿਤੁ ਕਿਤੁ ਬਿਧਿ ਜਗੁ ਉਪਜੈ ਪੁਰਖਾ ਕਿਤੁ ਕਿਤੁ ਦੁਖਿ ਬਿਨਸਿ ਜਾਈ ॥
section: Ramkali - Sidh Gosht (Conversations With The Perfected Masters)

translation.text: How, in what way, was the world formed, O man? And what disaster will end it?

transliteration.text: kit kit bidh jag upajai purakhā kit kit dukh binas jāī .

melody.description: The emotions in Ramkali are like those of a wise teacher disciplining their student. The student is aware of the pain of learning, but is still conscious of the fact that ultimately it is for the best. In this way Ramkali conveys the change from all that we are familiar with, to something we are certain will be better.

One day he disappeared while having his morning bath and reappeared 3 days later and said: There is no Hindu and there is no Muslim. By saying this he meant that titles were meaningless because all of humanity is one and the light of God shines within everyone.

text: ਹਉਮੈ ਵਿਚਿ ਜਗੁ ਉਪਜੈ ਪੁਰਖਾ ਨਾਮਿ ਵਿਸਰਿਐ ਦੁਖੁ ਪਾਈ ॥
section: Ramkali - Sidh Gosht (Conversations With The Perfected Masters)

translation.text: In egotism, the world was formed, O man; forgetting the Naam, it suffers and dies.

transliteration.text: haumai vich jag upajai purakhā nām visariai dukh pāī .

melody.description: The emotions in Ramkali are like those of a wise teacher disciplining their student. The student is aware of the pain of learning, but is still conscious of the fact that ultimately it is for the best. In this way Ramkali conveys the change from all that we are familiar with, to something we are certain will be better.

text: ਗੁਰਮੁਖਿ ਹੋਵੈ ਸੁ ਗਿਆਨੁ ਤਤੁ ਬੀਚਾਰੈ ਹਉਮੈ ਸਬਦਿ ਜਲਾਏ ॥
section: Ramkali - Sidh Gosht (Conversations With The Perfected Masters)

translation.text: One who becomes Gurmukh contemplates the essence of spiritual wisdom; through the Shabad, he burns away his egotism.

transliteration.text: guramukh hōvai s giān tat bīchārai haumai sabad jalāē .

melody.description: The emotions in Ramkali are like those of a wise teacher disciplining their student. The student is aware of the pain of learning, but is still conscious of the fact that ultimately it is for the best. In this way Ramkali conveys the change from all that we are familiar with, to something we are certain will be better.

text: ਤਨੁ ਮਨੁ ਨਿਰਮਲੁ ਨਿਰਮਲ ਬਾਣੀ ਸਾਚੈ ਰਹੈ ਸਮਾਏ ॥
section: Ramkali - Sidh Gosht (Conversations With The Perfected Masters)

translation.text: His body and mind become immaculate, through the Immaculate Bani of the Word. He remains absorbed in Truth.

transliteration.text: tan man niramal niramal bānī sāchai rahai samāē .

melody.description: The emotions in Ramkali are like those of a wise teacher disciplining their student. The student is aware of the pain of learning, but is still conscious of the fact that ultimately it is for the best. In this way Ramkali conveys the change from all that we are familiar with, to something we are certain will be better.

text: ਨਾਮੇ ਨਾਮਿ ਰਹੈ ਬੈਰਾਗੀ ਸਾਚੁ ਰਖਿਆ ਉਰਿ ਧਾਰੇ ॥
section: Ramkali - Sidh Gosht (Conversations With The Perfected Masters)

translation.text: Through the Naam, the Name of the Lord, he remains detached; he enshrines the True Name in his heart.

transliteration.text: nāmē nām rahai bairāgī sāch rakhiā ur dhārē .

section: Ramkali - Sidh Gosht (Conversations With The Perfected Masters)

translation.text: O Nanak, without the Name, Yoga is never attained; reflect upon this in your heart, and see. ||68||

transliteration.text: nānak bin nāvai jōg kadē n hōvai dēkhah ridai bīchārē .68.

translation.text: Without serving the True Guru, Yoga is not attained;

author.author: Guru Nanak Dev
author.description:
Guru Nanak Dev Ji [1469 - 1539] was the first Guru of the Sikhs born in a village named Talwandi which is now called Nankana Sahib and is in Pakistan. As a child Guru Nanak spent most of his time in isolation and meditation. He slept only for a few hours, ate small quantities of food and spoke little.

One day he disappeared while having his morning bath and reappeared 3 days later and said: There is no Hindu and there is no Muslim. By saying this he meant that titles were meaningless because all of humanity is one and the light of God shines within everyone.

section: Ramkali - Sidh Gosht (Conversations With The Perfected Masters)

translation.text: The Gurmukh does not lose in the Court of the Lord.

melody.description: The emotions in Ramkali are like those of a wise teacher disciplining their student. section: Ramkali - Sidh Gosht (Conversations With The Perfected Masters)

translation.text: O Nanak, the Gurmukh realizes the Word of the Shabad. ||71||

text: ਸਬਦੈ ਕਾ ਨਿਬੇੜਾ ਸੁਣਿ ਤੂ ਅਉਧੂ ਬਿਨੁ ਨਾਵੈ ਜੋਗੁ ਨ ਹੋਈ ॥
section: Ramkali - Sidh Gosht (Conversations With The Perfected Masters)

translation.text: This is the essence of the Shabad - listen, you hermits and Yogis. Without the Name, there is no Yoga.

transliteration.text: sabadai kā nibērā sun tū audhū bin nāvai jōg n hōī .

text: ਨਾਮੇ ਰਾਤੇ ਅਨਦਿਨੁ ਮਾਤੇ ਨਾਮੈ ਤੇ ਸੁਖੁ ਹੋਈ ॥
section: Ramkali - Sidh Gosht (Conversations With The Perfected Masters)

translation.text: Those who are attuned to the Name, remain intoxicated night and day; through the Name, they find peace.

transliteration.text: nāmē rātē anadin mātē nāmai tē sukh hōī .

text: ਨਾਮੈ ਹੀ ਤੇ ਸਭੁ ਪਰਗਟੁ ਹੋਵੈ ਨਾਮੇ ਸੋਝੀ ਪਾਈ ॥
section: Ramkali - Sidh Gosht (Conversations With The Perfected Masters)

translation.text: Through the Name, everything is revealed; through the Name, understanding is obtained.

transliteration.text: nāmai hī tē sabh paragat hōvai nāmē sōjhī pāī .

text: ਬਿਨੁ ਨਾਵੈ ਭੇਖ ਕਰਹਿ ਬਹੁਤੇਰੇ ਸਚੈ ਆਪਿ ਖੁਆਈ ॥
section: Ramkali - Sidh Gosht (Conversations With The Perfected Masters)

translation.text: Without the Name, people wear all sorts of religious robes; the True Lord Himself has confused them.

transliteration.text: bin nāvai bhēkh karah bahutērē sachai āp khuāī .

text: ਸਤਿਗੁਰ ਤੇ ਨਾਮੁ ਪਾਈਐ ਅਉਧੂ ਜੋਗ ਜੁਗਤਿ ਤਾ ਹੋਈ ॥
section: Ramkali - Sidh Gosht (Conversations With The Perfected Masters)

translation.text: The Name is obtained only from the True Guru, O hermit, and then, the Way of Yoga is found.

transliteration.text: satigur tē nām pāīai audhū jōg jugat tā hōī .

text: ਕਰਿ ਬੀਚਾਰੁ ਮਨਿ ਦੇਖਹੁ ਨਾਨਕ ਬਿਨੁ ਨਾਵੈ ਮੁਕਤਿ ਨ ਹੋਈ ॥੭੨॥
section: Ramkali - Sidh Gosht (Conversations With The Perfected Masters)

translation.text: Reflect upon this in your mind, and see; O Nanak, without the Name, there is no liberation. ||72||

transliteration.text: kar bīchār man dēkhah nānak bin nāvai mukat n hōī .72.

text: ਤੇਰੀ ਗਤਿ ਮਿਤਿ ਤੂਹੈ ਜਾਣਹਿ ਕਿਆ ਕੋ ਆਖਿ ਵਖਾਣੈ ॥
section: Ramkali - Sidh Gosht (Conversations With The Perfected Masters)

translation.text: You alone know Your state and extent, Lord; What can anyone say about it?

transliteration.text: tērī gat mit tūhai jānah kiā kō ākh vakhānai .

text: ਤੂ ਆਪੇ ਗੁਪਤਾ ਆਪੇ ਪਰਗਟੁ ਆਪੇ ਸਭਿ ਰੰਗ ਮਾਣੈ ॥
section: Ramkali - Sidh Gosht (Conversations With The Perfected Masters)

translation.text: You Yourself are hidden, and You Yourself are revealed. You Yourself enjoy all pleasures.

transliteration.text: tū āpē gupatā āpē paragat āpē sabh rang mānai .

section: Ramkali - Sidh Gosht (Conversations With The Perfected Masters)

translation.text: The seekers, the Siddhas, the many gurus and disciples wander around searching for You, according to Your Will.

transliteration.text: sādhik sidh gurū bah chēlē khōjat phirah phuramānai .

text: ਮਾਗਹਿ ਨਾਮੁ ਪਾਇ ਇਹ ਭਿਖਿਆ ਤੇਰੇ ਦਰਸਨ ਕਉ ਕੁਰਬਾਣੈ ॥
section: Ramkali - Sidh Gosht (Conversations With The Perfected Masters)

translation.text: They beg for Your Name, and You bless them with this charity. I am a sacrifice to the Blessed Vision of Your Darshan.

transliteration.text: māgah nām pāi ih bhikhiā tērē darasan kau kurabānai .

section: Ramkali - Sidh Gosht (Conversations With The Perfected Masters)

translation.text: The eternal imperishable Lord God has staged this play; the Gurmukh understands it.

transliteration.text: abināsī prabh khēl rachāiā guramukh sōjhī hōī .

section: Ramkali - Sidh Gosht (Conversations With The Perfected Masters)

translation.text: O Nanak, He extends Himself throughout the ages; there is no other than Him. ||73||1||

transliteration.text: nānak sabh jug āpē varatai dūjā avar n kōī .73.1.
